questions.text: Rat tail appearance is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Carcinoma Esophagus Rat tail appearance is a radiological sign seen in barium swallow studies of patients with carcinoma of the esophagus. It is characterized by: Irregular narrowing of the esophagus. Tapering with shouldered margins due to tumor infiltration and luminal obstruction. It is seen in advanced esophageal malignancies where the tumor causes a progressive luminal constriction. Incorrect Options: A. Achalasia Cardia In achalasia cardia, the lower esophageal sphincter fails to relax, causing gradual, smooth, symmetric narrowing of the distal esophagus, resembling a bird's beak rather than a rat tail. No irregular margins are seen. B. Reflux Esophagitis Chronic acid reflux leads to mucosal inflammation, strictures, and ulceration but does not produce a rat tail appearance. Instead, it may cause irregular mucosal thickening and narrowing. D. Hiatus Hernia A hiatal hernia occurs when part of the stomach protrudes through the diaphragmatic hiatus. It is seen as a gas-filled structure above the diaphragm on a barium study, but does not cause a rat tail narrowing.

questions.text: Pipe stem colon is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ulcerative Colitis The "pipe-stem colon" or "lead-pipe appearance" is a classic radiological finding seen in ulcerative colitis (UC) on a barium enema. This appearance results from loss of haustrations, leading to a smooth, featureless, and narrowed colon. Ulcerative colitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the mucosa and submucosa of the colon, typically starting in the rectum and extending proximally in a continuous pattern. Long-standing inflammation causes fibrosis, muscular hypertrophy, and loss of normal colonic folds, leading to the characteristic rigid, tubular colon resembling a lead pipe or pipe stem. Why Other Options Are Incorrect: B. Carcinoma Colon Carcinoma of the colon presents as an irregular, asymmetric, and shouldered stricture rather than a smooth, featureless narrowing. Radiologically, it is often associated with the "apple-core lesion", not a lead-pipe appearance. Unlike UC, the lesion is typically focal rather than diffuse. C. Crohn’s Disease Crohn’s disease affects the entire gastrointestinal tract and is transmural, leading to skip lesions, fistulae, and strictures. A characteristic radiographic finding in Crohn’s disease is the "string sign" due to marked luminal narrowing from fibrosis. Unlike UC, Crohn’s disease spares the rectum, has a segmental distribution, and does not cause uniform haustral loss. D. Whipple’s Disease Whipple’s disease is a rare bacterial infection affecting the small intestine, not primarily the colon. It presents with malabsorption, diarrhea, and weight loss, rather than strictures or loss of haustrations. Radiographically, it shows dilated bowel loops with thickened folds, rather than the pipe-stem appearance.

questions.text: Coiled spring appearance on barium enema is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intussusception The "coiled spring appearance" on barium enema is a classic radiological finding seen in intussusception. This occurs when one segment of the intestine telescopes into an adjacent segment, leading to mucosal folds trapped within the invaginated segment. The barium enema outlines these alternating layers of mucosa and barium, creating a coiled or spring-like pattern. Intussusception is most common in children under 2 years and is often idiopathic or due to lymphoid hyperplasia (e.g., after viral infections like rotavirus). In adults, it is usually caused by a leading point lesion such as a tumor, polyp, or Meckel’s diverticulum. Incorrect Options: A. Carcinoma Colon Colon cancer presents as an irregular, shouldered stricture rather than a coiled spring pattern. A typical radiological finding in carcinoma of the colon is the "apple-core lesion", due to an annular constricting tumor. B. Sigmoid Volvulus Sigmoid volvulus causes twisting of the sigmoid colon around its mesentery, leading to a "coffee bean sign" on X-ray and a "bird's beak" appearance on contrast studies. The barium enema shows a narrow, tapered obstruction at the site of the twist, not the coiled spring pattern. D. Ileal Atresia Ileal atresia is a congenital condition causing bowel obstruction due to a failure in fetal intestinal development. The classic radiological finding in ileal atresia is the "triple bubble sign", rather than a coiled spring appearance.

questions.text: Widening of C-loop of duodenum/broad loop of duodenum on X-ray is diagnostic of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Carcinoma Head of Pancreas Widening of the C-loop of the duodenum or a broad duodenal loop on an X-ray or barium study is a characteristic finding in carcinoma of the head of the pancreas. The head of the pancreas is located adjacent to the C-shaped curve of the duodenum (formed by the first, second, and third parts). When a tumor grows in the pancreatic head, it can cause extrinsic compression and widening of the C-loop, sometimes with delayed gastric emptying due to obstruction. Barium studies may also show irregular filling defects or indentations in the duodenum due to tumor infiltration. Incorrect Options: A. Chronic Pancreatitis Chronic pancreatitis may cause duodenal narrowing due to fibrosis and scarring, but not a broadening of the C-loop. It is more commonly associated with pancreatic calcifications, dilated pancreatic duct (chain of lakes appearance), and duodenal strictures rather than C-loop widening. C. Periampullary Carcinoma Periampullary carcinoma (cancer arising near the ampulla of Vater, including duodenal, pancreatic, or bile duct origin) can cause obstructive jaundice, but it does not characteristically widen the C-loop like pancreatic head cancer. It may show irregular narrowing of the duodenum instead. D. Calculi in Ampulla of Vater A stone in the ampulla of Vater can cause biliary and pancreatic duct obstruction, leading to jaundice and pancreatitis, but it does not widen the C-loop. Instead, it may cause filling defects in the duodenal papilla or dilated bile ducts on imaging.

questions.text: Intraductal calcification of pancreas is seen in all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hypoparathyroidism Intraductal calcifications in the pancreas are a hallmark of chronic pancreatitis and result from long-standing inflammation, fibrosis, and ductal obstruction. They are commonly seen in: Tropical pancreatitis (A) – A type of chronic pancreatitis seen in tropical regions, especially in young individuals, characterized by extensive intraductal calcifications. Alcoholic pancreatitis (B) – Chronic alcohol consumption leads to protein plugs and calcification within pancreatic ducts. Kwashiorkor (D) – Severe malnutrition, especially protein deficiency, has been associated with pancreatic damage and some degree of calcification in chronic cases.

questions.text: Chain of lakes appearance on ERCP is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Chronic Relapsing Pancreatitis The "chain of lakes" appearance on Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) refers to irregular dilation and narrowing of the pancreatic duct, resembling a chain of interconnected lakes. This pattern occurs due to chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and ductal obstruction leading to strictures and dilatations. Repeated episodes of pancreatic inflammation cause fibrosis and stenosis of the pancreatic ducts, leading to segmental dilatation. Seen in alcoholic pancreatitis and tropical pancreatitis. ERCP shows multiple strictures with intervening dilations, forming the characteristic "chain of lakes" pattern. Incorrect Options: Choledocholithiasis (A) Refers to gallstones in the common bile duct (CBD). ERCP typically shows a single dilated duct with an obstructing stone, not a chain of lakes pattern. Traumatic Pancreatitis (C) Trauma can lead to ductal disruption, but it usually results in pseudocysts or focal ductal injury, rather than diffuse irregular ductal dilations. Carcinoma Head of Pancreas (D) Pancreatic head tumors cause proximal dilation of the pancreatic duct due to obstruction. It does not produce a "chain of lakes" pattern but rather a single, smooth dilatation of the pancreatic duct (double duct sign).

questions.text: Investigation of choice for diagnosis of acute pancreatitis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CT Scan with Contrast The investigation of choice for diagnosing acute pancreatitis is contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) scan. CECT provides detailed imaging of the pancreas, showing inflammation, necrosis, and complications such as pseudocysts, abscesses, and vascular involvement. It helps assess disease severity using the Modified CT Severity Index (CTSI) or Balthazar scoring system. Necrotizing pancreatitis is best detected on CECT, where non-enhancing areas indicate ischemia or necrosis. Ideal timing for CECT: 48–72 hours after symptom onset to allow better visualization of necrosis and complications. Incorrect Options: A. USG Ultrasound (USG) is the first-line test but not the best for definitive diagnosis of pancreatitis. USG is useful for detecting gallstones (if gallstone pancreatitis is suspected) but pancreatic visualization is often limited due to overlying bowel gas. It is less sensitive than CT for assessing pancreatic necrosis and complications. B. Plain CT Scan A non-contrast CT may help identify pancreatic swelling, but it fails to differentiate viable from necrotic pancreatic tissue. It also misses vascular involvement and peripancreatic complications. Contrast enhancement is necessary to differentiate between viable and necrotic pancreatic tissue. D. MRI Scan MRI (especially MRCP – Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) is useful for biliary and ductal anatomy assessment, particularly in biliary pancreatitis. However, it is less commonly used in acute settings due to longer scan time and cost. MRI is superior to CT in detecting pancreatic fluid collections but is not the first-line imaging modality for acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pylori stenosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) USG (Ultrasound) The investigation of choice for diagnosing congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is Ultrasound (USG). USG is non-invasive, highly sensitive (>90%), and radiation-free, making it ideal for infants. It provides a real-time view of the hypertrophied pyloric muscle, showing: Thickened pyloric muscle (>3–4 mm in thickness) Elongated pyloric canal (>16–18 mm in length) Failure of gastric contents to pass through the pylorus USG also allows for dynamic assessment (seeing how the pyloric canal behaves). Incorrect Options: B. Barium Meal Barium meal can show the "string sign" (thin trickle of contrast through the narrowed pyloric canal), but it is not the first-line investigation. It exposes the infant to radiation and does not provide direct measurement of pyloric thickness. C. Barium Meal Follow Through This test is used for small bowel pathologies (e.g., malrotation, obstruction) but is not ideal for pyloric stenosis. It takes longer, involves radiation, and does not directly assess pyloric muscle thickness. D. CT Scan with Contrast CT is not required for diagnosing CHPS and exposes the infant to unnecessary radiation. It is used for complex cases where other abnormalities are suspected.

questions.text: All of the following are features of splenic rupture on plain X-ray abdomen except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Obliteration of colonic air bubble Splenic rupture is a serious condition that leads to intra-abdominal hemorrhage, which can present with radiological signs on a plain X-ray abdomen. The most common features of splenic rupture include: Obliteration of psoas shadow (Option A): Due to blood accumulation in the retroperitoneal space, the normal visualization of the psoas muscle shadow is lost. Obliteration of splenic outline (Option B): The spleen becomes indistinct due to a large hematoma or blood collection surrounding it. Elevation of the left hemidiaphragm (Option D): Blood and irritation of the diaphragm lead to reactive diaphragmatic elevation. However, the colonic air bubble (Option C) remains unaffected, as the blood from the ruptured spleen does not enter the intestinal lumen. Incorrect Options: A. Obliteration of psoas shadow Due to blood accumulation in the retroperitoneum, obscuring the normal psoas shadow. B. Obliteration of splenic outline A large perisplenic hematoma makes the spleen difficult to visualize on X-ray. D. Elevation of the left hemidiaphragm Due to subphrenic hemorrhage and irritation, the diaphragm gets elevated on the left side.

questions.text: Pantomography is done for except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Transverse fracture of Atlas. Pantomography (Panoramic Radiography) is a specialized imaging technique primarily used in dentistry and maxillofacial imaging. It provides a wide, curved, two-dimensional view of the entire dental arch, jaws, and temporomandibular joints (TMJ) in a single image. However, it is not suitable for evaluating cervical spine fractures, such as a transverse fracture of the atlas (C1 vertebra). Atlas fractures require more detailed imaging techniques, such as lateral cervical spine X-ray, open-mouth odontoid view, or CT scan, which offer superior bone resolution and visualization of the C1-C2 complex. Since pantomography does not effectively capture the cervical vertebrae, it is not a preferred modality for diagnosing an atlas fracture. Incorrect Options: A. Dental Caries Pantomography is widely used in dental examinations for detecting dental caries (cavities), periodontal disease, and impacted teeth. It helps visualize the entire dental arch and is useful for screening multiple teeth at once. B. Dental Cyst Pantomography is useful for detecting dental cysts and other pathological lesions in the jawbones, as it provides a comprehensive view of the upper and lower jaw structures. C. TM Joint It is also used for evaluating temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders, including joint degeneration, dislocation, and other abnormalities affecting jaw movement.

questions.text: String sign is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above The string sign refers to a narrowed segment of the intestine due to chronic inflammation, fibrosis, or hypertrophy, visible on barium studies as a thin, thread-like passage of contrast. This radiological sign is seen in multiple conditions affecting the gastrointestinal tract. A. Crohn's disease Crohn’s disease leads to chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and strictures in the bowel, commonly affecting the terminal ileum. On barium follow-through, the affected segment appears as a thin, narrowed passage, giving the classic string sign appearance. B. TB of the ileocaecal region Intestinal tuberculosis commonly affects the ileocaecal region, causing fibrotic strictures due to chronic inflammation. This results in a narrowed ileal lumen, which appears as a string-like passage of contrast on barium studies. C. Idiopathic hypertrophic pyloric stenosis In hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS), the thickened pyloric muscle causes gastric outlet obstruction, leading to a thin stream of contrast passing through the narrowed pyloric canal. This elongated, narrowed pylorus appears as a string sign on a barium meal X-ray.

questions.text: The substance used of OCG is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lopanoic acid Oral Cholecystography (OCG) is a radiological procedure used to visualize the gallbladder and assess its function. The contrast agent used in OCG must be absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract, excreted into bile, and provide good opacification of the gallbladder. Iopanoic acid is an iodinated contrast agent that is absorbed in the intestine, reaches the liver via the bloodstream, and is excreted into bile. It helps in outlining the gallbladder on X-ray, making it useful for detecting gallstones, polyps, or functional issues. Incorrect Options: B. Sodium diatrizoate It is an intravenous contrast agent used in intravenous urography (IVU) and angiography, not OCG. It is not excreted into bile in significant amounts, making it unsuitable for gallbladder imaging. C. Meglumine iodothalamate This is a water-soluble iodinated contrast medium used in renal imaging and myelography, but not for gallbladder studies. D. Biligraffin Although biligraffin is used in biliary imaging, it is primarily for intravenous cholangiography, not for oral cholecystography (OCG).

questions.text: Hot nodule is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Adenolymphoma (Warthin’s Tumor) A hot nodule refers to a lesion that actively takes up radioactive tracer (such as Tc-pertechnetate) during a nuclear medicine scan. In the case of salivary gland tumors, most are cold nodules, meaning they do not take up the tracer. However, there is one exception: Adenolymphoma (Warthin’s Tumor) is the only salivary gland tumor that appears as a hot nodule on Tc-pertechnetate scan due to its ability to concentrate the tracer. Incorrect Options: B. Mixed Parotid Tumor (Pleomorphic Adenoma) The most common benign salivary gland tumor, but it does not take up the tracer, making it a cold nodule on nuclear scans. C. Adenocystic Carcinoma A malignant salivary gland tumor that does not concentrate Tc-pertechnetate, making it cold on a scan. D. All Since only adenolymphoma (Warthin’s tumor) is a hot nodule, the answer cannot be "All."

questions.text: First radiological sign of Crohn's Disease in terminal ileum is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Aphthoid ulceration The first radiological sign of Crohn's disease in the terminal ileum is aphthoid ulceration, which appears as small, superficial, and well-defined ulcers on barium studies or cross-sectional imaging. These ulcers are early mucosal lesions seen before the development of more advanced changes like bowel wall thickening or cobblestoning. Aphthoid ulcers are the earliest lesions in Crohn's disease, appearing as small (1-2 mm) ulcers with a central depression and surrounding mucosal edema. Best visualized in barium follow-through or CT enterography. These ulcers later coalesce and progress to deeper ulcerations, forming the characteristic cobblestone appearance. Incorrect Options: B. Pseudo-sacculations Pseudo-sacculations occur later due to fibrosis and asymmetric bowel wall thickening, leading to the formation of sacculation on the anti-mesenteric border. They are not an early sign but appear after chronic inflammation. C. Cobblestone Pattern The cobblestone appearance results from ulcers separating islands of inflamed mucosa, giving a "cobblestone" look. It is a later stage finding, not an earliest radiological sign. D. Thickening of Bowel Wall Bowel wall thickening occurs due to chronic transmural inflammation and fibrosis. It is seen in advanced Crohn’s disease, not in the early phase.

questions.text: In X-ray ,jejunum has a pattern of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Valvulae Conniventes The jejunum has a characteristic radiological pattern due to the presence of valvulae conniventes, also known as Kerckring’s folds. These are transverse mucosal folds that extend completely across the lumen of the jejunum, giving it a feathery appearance on barium studies (Barium Meal Follow-Through). Valvulae conniventes are mucosal folds that are more numerous, thicker, and closely spaced in the jejunum compared to the ileum. On X-ray with barium contrast, the jejunum shows a feathery or coiled-spring appearance, due to these folds. This pattern helps differentiate the jejunum from the ileum, where folds are less prominent. Incorrect Options: B. Taenia Coli Taenia coli are three longitudinal muscle bands found in the colon, not in the jejunum. They are responsible for the formation of haustra (sacculations) in the large intestine. The jejunum lacks taenia coli and instead has valvulae conniventes. C. Reverse 3 Sign The reverse 3 sign is seen in annular carcinoma of the pancreas, where the pancreatic mass compresses the duodenum, giving a shape similar to a reversed number 3. It is not related to jejunal anatomy or pattern. D. None of the Above Since valvulae conniventes are a defining feature of the jejunum, option A is the correct answer.

questions.text: Most common cause of target lesion in Stomach is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Melanoma The target lesion in the stomach is a characteristic radiological appearance seen on imaging studies like CT scan or barium meal studies. It is caused by concentric layers of varying densities due to tumor infiltration. Melanoma is the most common metastatic tumor to the stomach and is the most common cause of target lesions in the stomach. It appears as multiple, round, well-defined lesions with central ulceration and surrounding edema, giving the classic "bull’s eye" or target lesion appearance. Metastatic melanoma spreads hematogenously and frequently involves the gastrointestinal tract, particularly the stomach and small intestine. Incorrect Options: B. Lymphoma – Does Not Typically Show Target Lesion Gastric lymphoma usually presents as diffuse thickening of the gastric wall rather than distinct target lesions. It can cause large, infiltrative masses but does not commonly present with the bull’s eye appearance. C. Carcinoid – More Often a Submucosal Mass Gastric carcinoid tumors originate from enterochromaffin-like cells and typically appear as submucosal nodules. They do not usually form target lesions but may present as enhancing masses on imaging. D. Fibroma – Rare and Not a Typical Cause of Target Lesions Fibromas are benign mesenchymal tumors that appear as homogeneous soft tissue masses. They do not commonly produce the target lesion appearance seen in metastatic melanoma.

questions.text: Best diagnosis of pancreatic Cancer (head) is by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CT Scan The best diagnostic modality for detecting pancreatic cancer (especially in the head of the pancreas) is contrast-enhanced CT (CECT scan). CT scan provides detailed imaging of the pancreas, allowing for: Tumor localization and assessment of size and extent Detection of vascular invasion (involvement of major vessels like the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and portal vein) Identification of metastases to liver, lymph nodes, or peritoneum Evaluation of biliary and pancreatic duct dilation (double duct sign) CT is the gold standard for staging pancreatic cancer and determining resectability, which is crucial for treatment planning. Incorrect Options: A. Ultrasound Transabdominal ultrasound is often the first imaging modality used for jaundiced patients, as it can detect biliary duct dilation. However, it is not reliable for detecting small tumors in the head of the pancreas due to limitations from bowel gas and obesity. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is superior to transabdominal ultrasound but is still secondary to CT scan for diagnosis and staging. B. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) ERCP is useful for detecting biliary obstruction (due to pancreatic head tumors) and for placing biliary stents in obstructive jaundice. However, it is not the best primary diagnostic tool because it does not assess tumor extent, size, or vascular involvement as effectively as CT. D. Angiography Angiography is primarily used in vascular assessment, especially in cases where surgical resection is being considered. While CT angiography can assess vascular involvement, conventional angiography is rarely used for initial diagnosis.

questions.text: Best investigation for diagnosis of ampullary gall stone with obstructive jaundice is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) The best investigation for diagnosing an ampullary gallstone causing obstructive jaundice is ERCP because: It provides direct visualization of the ampulla of Vater, common bile duct (CBD), and pancreatic duct. It allows for both diagnosis and treatment by detecting choledocholithiasis and enabling stone extraction using sphincterotomy. ERCP is highly sensitive and specific for detecting small ampullary stones, which may not be well visualized on ultrasound or CT. It helps in relieving obstruction by placing a stent if needed. Incorrect Options: A. Intravenous Cholecystography (IVC) IVC is not useful for detecting ampullary or CBD stones. It primarily assesses gallbladder function and stones inside the gallbladder, not bile duct obstruction. B. Oral Cholecystography (OCG) Like IVC, OCG is used for gallbladder imaging, but it is not helpful for evaluating the biliary ducts or ampullary region. C. Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography (PTC) PTC is used for obstructed biliary systems, especially in cases where ERCP is unsuccessful or not feasible (e.g., post-surgical anatomy). However, it is more invasive than ERCP and does not allow for therapeutic interventions like stone removal.

questions.text: Best diagnosis of Trachea esophageal fistula is by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dianosil The best diagnostic contrast agent for tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) is Dianosil, a water-soluble contrast medium. Dianosil is preferred over barium sulfate because barium can cause severe inflammation and granuloma formation if aspirated into the lungs. TEF is typically diagnosed using contrast esophagography, where a small amount of water-soluble contrast is administered to check for leakage into the trachea. Incorrect Options: A. Barium Sulphate – Not Safe for TEF Diagnosis Barium should be avoided in suspected TEF because it can cause severe chemical pneumonitis if aspirated. It is not water-soluble, making it dangerous in cases of potential aspiration. B. Conray 240 – Not Typically Used for TEF Conray 240 is an iodinated contrast agent primarily used for angiography, CT scans, and intravenous urography, not for esophageal studies. D. Urograffin – Can Be Used but Not the Best Choice Urograffin is also a water-soluble contrast but is more hypertonic and may cause irritation or complications if aspirated. Dianosil is preferred due to its better safety profile for detecting TEF.

questions.text: Chain of lakes appearance on xray is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chronic Pancreatitis The "Chain of Lakes" appearance on X-ray or ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) is characteristic of chronic pancreatitis due to: Irregular dilatation and narrowing of the pancreatic duct caused by fibrosis, inflammation, and calcification. Formation of multiple strictures and dilations, resembling a series of connected lakes on imaging. It is most commonly seen in alcohol-induced chronic pancreatitis, but can also occur in tropical pancreatitis and idiopathic cases. Incorrect Options: B. Acute Pancreatitis Acute pancreatitis does not cause chronic ductal changes like strictures and dilatations. Imaging findings in acute pancreatitis include diffuse gland enlargement, peripancreatic fluid collections, and fat stranding, but not the "Chain of Lakes" sign. C. Carcinoma of Head of Pancreas Carcinoma of the pancreas typically causes a single focal stricture or obstruction of the pancreatic duct rather than the diffuse irregular dilatation seen in chronic pancreatitis. Imaging often shows a hypoechoic mass and double duct sign (simultaneous dilation of the pancreatic and bile ducts). D. Adenocarcinoma Adenocarcinoma leads to a single stenotic lesion rather than multiple ductal dilations as seen in chronic pancreatitis. It presents with progressive bile duct obstruction, pancreatic atrophy, and metastases, rather than the irregular "Chain of Lakes" appearance.

questions.text: Double bubble sign is a Radiological feature of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Duodenal Atresia The "Double Bubble Sign" is a classic radiological feature of duodenal atresia, seen on abdominal X-ray or ultrasound. It appears as: Two prominent air-filled bubbles in the stomach and proximal duodenum separated by the atretic or stenotic duodenum. No distal bowel gas, since the atresia prevents air from passing beyond the duodenum. It is congenital and commonly associated with Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). Incorrect Options: A. Pyloric Stenosis Pyloric stenosis causes gastric outlet obstruction, but it does not produce the "Double Bubble Sign." The key radiological feature of pyloric stenosis is the "string sign" on an upper GI contrast study, showing a thin stream of contrast passing through a hypertrophic pyloric canal. C. Hirschsprung’s Disease Hirschsprung’s disease leads to a functional obstruction of the colon due to aganglionosis, causing a dilated proximal colon and a narrow rectosigmoid ("Transition Zone") on contrast enema. It does not cause the double bubble appearance, as the pathology is in the colon, not the duodenum. D. Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC) NEC presents with distended bowel loops, pneumatosis intestinalis (gas in bowel wall), and portal venous gas rather than the double bubble sign. It primarily affects preterm infants due to intestinal ischemia and infection, leading to perforation and peritonitis.

questions.text: Barium meal picture of carcinoma Stomach shows:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) All of the above A barium meal study in a patient with carcinoma of the stomach typically reveals multiple radiological features that together help in the diagnosis. Carcinoma of the stomach often presents with a filling defect, loss of the normal mucosal rugosity, a reduced (small) gastric capacity, and delayed emptying of barium, reflecting the tumor's infiltration and the functional impairment of the stomach. A. Filling Defect Filling defects are seen when the tumor mass protrudes into the lumen, causing an irregular contour that interrupts the normal flow of barium. This sign is one of the direct evidences of an intraluminal lesion. B. Loss of Rugosity Carcinoma disrupts the normal mucosal pattern of the stomach. The loss of rugosity indicates that the normal folds (rugae) have been effaced by the infiltrative process, a characteristic feature of malignant involvement. C. Small Capacity of Stomach In advanced gastric carcinoma, particularly those with diffuse infiltrative (linitis plastica) patterns, the stomach becomes rigid and its capacity diminishes. This small capacity is due to extensive fibrosis and tumor infiltration. D. Delayed Emptying of Barium Due to the disruption of the normal muscular function and luminal narrowing, there is delayed emptying of barium. This functional impairment is another key indicator of gastric malignancy.

questions.text: Bird beak appearance of distal oeso­phagus is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Achalasia Cardia The "bird beak" appearance of the distal esophagus is a classic radiological finding in achalasia cardia. On a barium swallow study, the distal esophagus tapers smoothly into a narrow segment due to the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax. This tapering closely resembles the beak of a bird and is considered diagnostic for achalasia, which is an esophageal motility disorder characterized by impaired peristalsis and incomplete LES relaxation. Incorrect Options: B. Reflux Esophagitis Reflux esophagitis typically shows mucosal irregularity, ulcerations, or strictures in the distal esophagus rather than the smooth, tapering narrowing seen in achalasia. C. Carcinoma Oesophagus Carcinoma of the esophagus generally presents with an irregular, asymmetric narrowing often described as an "apple-core" lesion, not the uniform tapering characteristic of a "bird beak" sign. D. Hiatus Hernia A hiatus hernia is identified by the herniation of the stomach through the diaphragmatic hiatus, which may cause a bulge at the esophagogastric junction but does not produce the smooth, tapering "bird beak" narrowing of the distal esophagus

questions.text: Medusa lock appearance in xray is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ascaris The "Medusa head" or "Medusa lock" appearance on X-ray is classically associated with Ascaris lumbricoides infestation. When Ascaris worms invade the biliary tree or become calcified in the abdomen, they can appear as multiple radiating, serpentine densities that resemble the head of Medusa, with its characteristic snake-like projections. This radiological pattern is a hallmark of Ascaris infection in endemic areas. Incorrect Options: B. Tapeworm Tapeworms are long, segmented parasites that tend to appear as elongated, continuous structures on imaging. They do not typically produce a radiographic pattern resembling a "Medusa head." C. Hookworm Hookworms are very small intestinal parasites and do not calcify or produce visible radiographic features like the "Medusa head" sign on X-ray. D. Ascaris and Tapeworm While Ascaris can produce the "Medusa head" appearance, tapeworms do not contribute to this pattern. Therefore, this combined option is not correct because only Ascaris is responsible for the characteristic appearance.

questions.text: CT findings of acute pancreatitis are all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dilatation of Pancreatic Duct On CT imaging of acute pancreatitis, typical findings include an edematous (swollen) pancreas, a fuzzy or ill-defined pancreatic outline due to inflammatory changes, and parapancreatic fluid collections resulting from leakage of pancreatic enzymes and inflammation. These findings reflect the acute inflammatory process in the pancreas. Why Option A is Incorrect as a CT Finding in Acute Pancreatitis: Dilatation of the Pancreatic Duct is not typically a feature of acute pancreatitis. In acute pancreatitis, the main problem is inflammation and edema rather than ductal obstruction. Pancreatic duct dilatation is more commonly associated with chronic pancreatitis or obstructive processes (e.g., pancreatic head carcinoma) rather than an acute inflammatory episode. Incorrect Options: B. Fuzzy Outline of Pancreas The inflammatory process in acute pancreatitis leads to edema and peripancreatic fat stranding, which gives the pancreas a blurred, ill-defined (fuzzy) border on CT. C. Parapancreatic Fluid Collection Fluid collections adjacent to the pancreas are a hallmark of acute pancreatitis. They occur due to leakage of inflammatory exudate and pancreatic enzymes into the surrounding tissue. D. Edematous Pancreas The pancreas typically becomes swollen and enlarged due to inflammation in acute pancreatitis, which is clearly visible on CT imaging as an edematous pancreas.

questions.text: 'Scalloping' of the edge of sigmoid colon on barium enema seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pneumatosis intestinalis Scalloping of the edge of the sigmoid colon on barium enema is a characteristic radiological finding seen in Pneumatosis Intestinalis. Pneumatosis intestinalis is a rare condition where gas-filled cysts form in the submucosa or subserosa of the intestinal wall. On barium enema, the gas-filled cysts produce an irregular scalloped appearance along the edges of the colon. This condition can be idiopathic or associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), ischemia, infection, or steroid use. Incorrect Options: A. Diverticulosis – Produces Outpouchings, Not Scalloping Diverticulosis leads to multiple outpouchings of the colonic wall, which appear as rounded barium-filled structures rather than scalloping. The hallmark finding is a saw-tooth appearance rather than a scalloped border. B. Ulcerative Colitis – Lead Pipe Colon, Not Scalloping Ulcerative colitis causes loss of haustration leading to a lead pipe appearance, not scalloping. The colon appears smooth and featureless, unlike the irregular gas cysts seen in pneumatosis intestinalis. C. Carcinoma Colon – Apple-Core Lesion, Not Scalloping Colorectal carcinoma commonly presents as a "napkin ring" or "apple-core" lesion due to luminal narrowing from an obstructing mass. It does not typically cause scalloping of the colonic wall.

questions.text: Double buble sign in Xray abdomen is a sign of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Duodenal Atresia The "double bubble sign" on an abdominal X-ray is a classic radiological finding that is most commonly associated with duodenal atresia. This sign is characterized by the presence of two distinct air-filled bubbles: one in the stomach and the other in the proximal duodenum. The absence of gas beyond the second bubble indicates a complete obstruction of the duodenum, which is the hallmark of duodenal atresia. This condition is frequently seen in neonates and is often linked with Down syndrome. Incorrect Options: A. Annular Pancreas Although an annular pancreas can also cause a similar double bubble appearance due to extrinsic compression of the duodenum, it is less common than duodenal atresia and the radiological picture may sometimes be more variable. The classic presentation of the double bubble sign is most strongly associated with duodenal atresia. B. Ileal Atresia Ileal atresia causes obstruction further down in the small intestine, and the X-ray typically shows multiple dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels, not just two isolated bubbles. C. Anal Rectal Malformation Anal rectal malformations affect the distal gastrointestinal tract. They do not produce the double bubble sign, but instead result in abnormal gas patterns in the lower abdomen, such as a gasless rectum or a variable amount of proximal bowel distension.

questions.text: lymphangio myomatosis is characterised by all of the following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Post Menopausal Women Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is a rare lung disease that predominantly affects women of reproductive age (typically 20-40 years old), not post-menopausal women. It is characterized by the proliferation of abnormal smooth muscle-like cells that lead to cystic destruction of the lungs, along with lymphatic involvement. Post Menopausal Women are not typically affected by LAM. The disease almost exclusively occurs in premenopausal women due to hormonal influences (notably estrogen), making this option the exception among the listed features. Incorrect Options: B. Recurrent Chylous Pleural Effusion LAM frequently leads to the formation of chylous pleural effusions due to lymphatic obstruction and leakage of chyle into the pleural space, which is a well-known clinical feature. C. Ascites Ascites can occur in LAM as a result of lymphatic obstruction in the abdomen, leading to the accumulation of lymphatic fluid within the peritoneal cavity. D. Recurrent Spontaneous Pneumothorax Recurrent spontaneous pneumothorax is a common complication in LAM due to the rupture of the cystic lesions within the lungs.

questions.text: Most sensitive investigation for pancreatic carcinoma is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) CT Scan CT scan, especially a contrast-enhanced CT scan, is considered the most sensitive investigation for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma. It allows for detailed evaluation of the pancreatic parenchyma, delineation of the tumor, assessment of local vascular invasion, and detection of metastases. CT is widely used for both the diagnosis and staging of pancreatic cancer, making it the gold standard imaging modality in this setting. Incorrect Options: A. Angiography Angiography is mainly used to evaluate vascular involvement and for planning surgical resection. It is invasive and is not primarily used for the initial detection of pancreatic carcinoma. B. ERCP ERCP is excellent for visualizing the pancreatic and bile ducts and can detect ductal strictures or the "double duct" sign. However, it is invasive, less sensitive for detecting the actual mass, and is mainly used when endoscopic intervention (such as stenting) is required. C. Ultrasound Transabdominal ultrasound is often the first imaging modality used due to its noninvasiveness and ease of use. However, it is operator-dependent and less sensitive for detecting small pancreatic lesions or accurately assessing local invasion compared to CT scan.

choices.text: Calculi in the ampulla of water

questions.text: Widening of the C loop in xray is diagnostic of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Carcinoma Head of Pancreas Widening of the C-loop of the duodenum on an abdominal X-ray or barium study is classically associated with a mass in the head of the pancreas. In carcinoma of the pancreatic head, the tumor often exerts extrinsic pressure on the duodenum, leading to a broadening or widening of its C-shaped curve. This radiographic sign helps differentiate it from other pathologies, as the enlarged pancreatic head distorts the normal contour of the duodenum. Incorrect Options: A. Chronic Pancreatitis Chronic pancreatitis typically presents with pancreatic calcifications, ductal dilatation, and an irregular pancreatic contour rather than causing a consistent widening of the duodenal C-loop. C. Periampullary Carcinoma Although periampullary carcinoma can cause obstructive symptoms, it usually leads to a focal obstruction at the ampulla with the "double duct sign" (dilation of both the bile and pancreatic ducts) rather than a diffuse widening of the C-loop. D. Calculi in the Ampulla of Vater Calculi in the ampulla of Vater may cause biliary obstruction and can sometimes be visualized as filling defects on imaging, but they do not typically result in the extrinsic compression and subsequent widening of the duodenal C-loop.

questions.text: A neonate is brought with history of not having passed meconium. on examination there is no anal opening but a dimple. Investigation of choice is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Invertogram In neonates with suspected imperforate anus—characterized by the absence of a normal anal opening and the presence of a dimple—the invertogram is the investigation of choice. This radiograph is taken with the neonate inverted (held upside down) which allows the air in the bowel to outline the rectal pouch. It helps determine the level of the rectal pouch relative to the perineum, which is crucial for surgical planning and deciding between a primary repair or a staged procedure. Incorrect Options: A. X-ray Erect Posture An erect abdominal X-ray is not suitable for evaluating the level of the rectal pouch in neonates with imperforate anus. It does not provide the necessary information about the relationship of the rectal pouch to the perineum. B. X-ray Supine Posture A supine X-ray does not allow the air to rise into the rectal pouch in a way that clearly delineates its position relative to the perineum. This view is less helpful for planning the surgical approach. C. Gastrograffin Study A Gastrograffin study is typically used for evaluating the gastrointestinal tract, particularly in cases of suspected perforation or obstruction. It is not indicated for diagnosing or evaluating the level of an imperforate anus.

questions.text: Contrast material used in the diagnosis of esophageal atresia is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dianosil Dianosil is the preferred contrast material for diagnosing esophageal atresia due to its low viscosity and water solubility, making it safer for neonates. Esophageal atresia is a congenital anomaly where the esophagus is interrupted or disconnected, preventing food passage to the stomach. To confirm the diagnosis, a contrast study is performed, ensuring that the contrast does not cause aspiration pneumonitis if it enters the lungs. Dianosil is water-soluble, making it safer than barium in case of aspiration. It provides good contrast to visualize the atretic segment and any associated tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). A. Barium Swallow – Risk of Aspiration Pneumonitis Barium is contraindicated in neonates with suspected esophageal atresia because it is not water-soluble and can cause severe chemical pneumonitis if aspirated. It is only used after surgical correction to check for leaks. B. Gastrograffin – Highly Hyperosmolar, Risk of Pulmonary Edema Gastrograffin is a water-soluble contrast agent, but it is highly hyperosmolar and can cause severe pulmonary edema if aspirated. It is not recommended for esophageal atresia diagnosis in neonates. C. Conray – Higher Risk of Aspiration Complications Conray is an iodinated contrast agent, but it is less commonly used in diagnosing esophageal atresia due to its higher viscosity and potential risk of complications if aspirated.

questions.text: A patient has calcification on AP view of right side of abdomen. In lateral view, calcification is seen to overlie the spine. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Renal Stones Renal stones are typically located in the retroperitoneal space, near the spine. On an AP (anteroposterior) view of the abdomen, a calcification in the region of the right kidney may appear on the right side. On the lateral view, because the kidneys are retroperitoneal, the calcification will be seen to overlie the spine. This positional correlation is characteristic of renal stones. Incorrect Options: A. Gall Stone Gallstones are usually located in the gallbladder, which is an intraperitoneal structure located in the right upper quadrant. On a lateral view, gallstones would appear more anterior and would not typically overlie the spine. B. Calcified Mesenteric Nodes Calcified mesenteric nodes are located within the mesentery, an intraperitoneal structure. They tend to be more centrally located and, on lateral view, would not consistently overlie the spine, as they are not retroperitoneal. D. Calcification of Vertebral Spinous Process Calcification of a vertebral spinous process is indeed seen over the spine on both AP and lateral views. However, on the AP view, such calcification would appear in the midline rather than on the right side of the abdomen.

questions.text: The radiological feature of pindborg’s tumour is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Driven Snow Appearance Pindborg’s tumor, also known as the Calcifying Epithelial Odontogenic Tumor (CEOT), characteristically shows a "driven snow appearance" on radiographs. This appearance is due to the presence of numerous small calcifications within the lesion, which are scattered in a pattern resembling fresh, fine snow driven by the wind. The driven snow pattern is considered a hallmark of CEOT and helps differentiate it from other odontogenic tumors. Incorrect Options: A. Onion Peel Appearance The onion peel appearance is typically seen in Ewing's sarcoma and is characterized by layered periosteal reactions, not by the calcifications seen in CEOT. B. Sunburst Appearance A sunburst appearance is classically associated with osteogenic sarcoma (osteosarcoma) due to aggressive periosteal reaction, which is not a feature of Pindborg’s tumor. D. Cherry Blossom Appearance The cherry blossom appearance is not a recognized radiological sign for Pindborg’s tumor or other common odontogenic tumors. It does not describe the pattern of calcification observed in CEOT

questions.text: Chain of lakes appearance on xray is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chronic Pancreatitis The "chain of lakes" appearance on imaging is a classic finding in chronic pancreatitis. This appearance is produced by multiple strictures interspersed with segmental dilatations along the pancreatic duct, which occurs due to long-standing inflammation, fibrosis, and recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. The resulting irregular duct with alternating narrow and widened segments is reminiscent of a chain of lakes. Incorrect Options: B. Acute Pancreatitis In acute pancreatitis, the primary findings are an edematous pancreas, peripancreatic fluid collections, and fat stranding rather than chronic ductal changes. The pancreatic duct does not typically exhibit the alternating strictures and dilatations seen in chronic pancreatitis. C. Carcinoma of Head of Pancreas Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas generally causes a focal obstruction of the pancreatic duct, leading to upstream dilation (often seen as the "double duct sign"), not the diffuse, irregular "chain of lakes" appearance characteristic of chronic pancreatitis. D. Adenocarcinoma Adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, being a malignant process, usually results in a single, focal stricture rather than multiple alternating strictures and dilatations in the duct. It does not produce the "chain of lakes" pattern seen in chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for small intestine tumour
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) CT scan with contrast is the investigation of choice for diagnosing small intestine tumors because it provides: Detailed cross-sectional imaging to detect masses, obstruction, or wall thickening. Enhanced visualization of the tumor’s vascularity and involvement of surrounding structures. Detection of lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. CT enterography (a specialized contrast-enhanced CT scan) improves visualization of mucosal and submucosal lesions. Incorrect Options: A. Barium Meal Follow-Through – Less Sensitivity Barium meal follow-through is an older modality used for detecting luminal abnormalities. It may show filling defects or strictures, but it is less sensitive than CT in detecting small tumors, extraluminal involvement, or metastases. B. Echo – Not Suitable for Intestinal Tumors Ultrasound (Echo) is not useful for diagnosing small intestine tumors due to gas interference in the bowel. It may help in identifying abdominal masses but lacks the detailed resolution needed. C. X-ray Abdomen – Limited Diagnostic Value A plain X-ray may show intestinal obstruction, perforation, or calcifications, but it cannot visualize tumors directly. It is nonspecific and does not provide the required detail for diagnosing small intestine tumors.

questions.text: The xray appearance of a CBD stone on cholangiography is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Meniscus Appearance On cholangiography, a common bile duct (CBD) stone typically appears as a filling defect within the opacified bile duct. The classic radiological description is that the stone produces a "meniscus appearance" – this refers to the characteristic concave, curved border formed by the contrast surrounding the stone. This meniscus effect is due to the partial coating of contrast around an intraluminal filling defect, which is most commonly seen with CBD stones. Incorrect Options: B. Eccentric Occlusion While a CBD stone may cause an eccentric filling defect, the term "eccentric occlusion" is less specific and not the classic descriptive sign. The key radiologic feature is the curved "meniscus" outline rather than simply an off-center occlusion. C. Sudden Cut Off A sudden cut off of contrast in the bile duct is more typical of a stricture or complete obstruction by a tumor rather than a stone. Stones usually produce a filling defect with a meniscus sign rather than an abrupt termination of the contrast column. D. Smooth Tapering Smooth tapering of the bile duct is usually seen in benign biliary strictures, where there is gradual narrowing of the lumen. This is not characteristic of a CBD stone, which is best identified by the focal filling defect with a meniscus appearance.

questions.text: Medusa head appearance on abdominal xray indicates
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Round Worm The "Medusa head" appearance on an abdominal X-ray is most typically associated with calcified Ascaris lumbricoides, which is a type of roundworm. When Ascaris worms become calcified in the abdomen or biliary system, they can produce a radiographic pattern that resembles the head of Medusa, with multiple radiating, serpiginous calcific strands. This finding is characteristic of a roundworm infestation and is seen in endemic areas. Incorrect Options: B. Tapeworm Tapeworms, although long and segmented, do not usually calcify in a manner that produces a "Medusa head" pattern on X-ray. Their radiographic appearances differ, often appearing as elongated, linear structures without the characteristic radiating calcifications. C. Roundworm and Tapeworm While roundworms (such as Ascaris) can cause the "Medusa head" appearance, tapeworms do not. Therefore, the combination is not correct because only roundworms are typically responsible for this radiologic sign. D. Amoebiasis Amoebiasis, an infection caused by Entamoeba histolytica, usually presents with features like colonic ulcers, flask-shaped lesions, or liver abscesses on imaging, and does not produce a "Medusa head" appearance on an abdominal X-ray.

questions.text: Which of the following is less useful diagnostic procedure in a case of acute hematemesis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Barium In the setting of acute hematemesis, performing a barium study is generally considered less useful and even contraindicated. Barium studies involve the ingestion of a contrast medium that coats the gastrointestinal lining, which can obscure the visualization of active bleeding and the mucosal details during subsequent endoscopy. Moreover, if barium is aspirated during an episode of active bleeding, it can lead to serious complications such as barium-induced pneumonitis. Incorrect Options: B. Endoscopy Endoscopy is the diagnostic procedure of choice in acute hematemesis because it allows direct visualization of the bleeding site. It also offers the opportunity for therapeutic intervention, such as cauterization, clipping, or injection therapy. C. Gastric Lavage Gastric lavage is useful in the initial evaluation of a patient with hematemesis. It helps clear the stomach of blood, which can improve the visualization during endoscopy and may provide diagnostic clues about the source of bleeding. D. Angiography Angiography can be very useful in cases where endoscopy fails to identify the bleeding source or if the bleeding is brisk and continuous. It can help localize the bleeding vessel and allow for therapeutic embolization.

questions.text: On radiography, widened duodenal C lop with irregular mucosal pattern on upper gastrointestinal barium series is most likely due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Carcinoma of Head of Pancreas The widened duodenal C-loop with an irregular mucosal pattern on an upper gastrointestinal barium series is most characteristically seen in carcinoma of the head of the pancreas. In this condition, the tumor in the pancreatic head exerts an external compressive effect on the adjacent duodenum, leading to a broadening of its C-shaped loop. Additionally, the irregularity of the mucosal pattern may result from direct tumor infiltration or secondary inflammatory changes. This extrinsic compression and distortion are hallmarks of carcinoma in this region, making it the most likely diagnosis when these radiographic features are present. Incorrect Options: A. Chronic Pancreatitis Chronic pancreatitis typically shows pancreatic calcifications and ductal irregularities on imaging. It does not usually cause a widened duodenal C-loop with an irregular mucosal pattern, as its effects are primarily within the pancreatic parenchyma rather than causing external compression of the duodenum. C. Duodenal Ulcer A duodenal ulcer generally produces a localized mucosal defect and may cause narrowing or deformity at the ulcer site. It does not lead to a generalized widening of the duodenal C-loop nor an irregular overall mucosal pattern, which are more indicative of an extrinsic mass effect. D. Duodenal Ileus Duodenal ileus, which refers to a functional obstruction or adynamic bowel, tends to cause diffuse dilatation of the bowel without the specific irregular mucosal pattern. It lacks the focal extrinsic compression seen in carcinoma of the head of the pancreas.

choices.text: Radiating folds which do not reach the edge of the ulcer
Lesser curvature ulcer with nodular rim

questions.text: Following are common features of malignant gastric ulcers on barium meal except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Location on the Greater Curvature Malignant gastric ulcers typically occur on the lesser curvature of the stomach, rather than on the greater curvature. On a barium meal, malignant ulcers characteristically show features such as irregular, nodular margins and radiating folds that do not extend to the edge of the ulcer, along with signs like Carman’s meniscus sign. Therefore, a location on the greater curvature is not a common feature of malignant gastric ulcers. Incorrect Options: B. Carman’s Meniscus Sign This sign is seen on barium studies of malignant gastric ulcers, where the ulcer edge creates a curved, meniscus-like contour due to the irregular undermined margins of the tumor. C. Radiating Folds Which Do Not Reach the Edge of the Ulcer In malignant gastric ulcers, the surrounding mucosal folds are often distorted and appear to radiate toward the ulcer without actually meeting its edge. This is due to the infiltrative nature of the cancer. D. Lesser Curvature Ulcer with Nodular Rim Malignant ulcers are most commonly found along the lesser curvature of the stomach and often display a nodular or irregular rim, which reflects the invasive growth pattern of the tumor.

choices.text: IV, V, VI, VII and VIII
I, V, VI, VII and VIII
I, IV, V, VI, VI and VIII

questions.text: The right lobe of liver consists of which of the following segments
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Segments V, VI, VII and VIII According to Couinaud’s segmentation of the liver, the right lobe is anatomically defined as comprising segments V, VI, VII, and VIII. These segments are separated from the left lobe by the falciform ligament and the ligamentum teres, and they are located on the right side of the liver. The right lobe is larger and contains these four segments, which are crucial for surgical planning and liver resection procedures. Incorrect Options:: B. Segments IV, V, VI, VII and VIII Segment IV is part of the left lobe (specifically the medial segment of the left lobe) and does not belong to the right lobe. Including segment IV incorrectly enlarges the right lobe. C. Segments I, V, VI, VII and VIII Segment I refers to the caudate lobe, which is a separate structure that lies posteriorly and is functionally distinct. The right lobe does not include the caudate lobe. D. Segments I, IV, V, VI, VII and VIII This option incorrectly includes both segment I (the caudate lobe) and segment IV (part of the left lobe) along with the right lobe segments. The right lobe is confined to segments V, VI, VII, and VIII.

questions.text: A solitary hypoechoic lesion of the liver withought septae or debris is most likely to be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Simple Cyst A simple cyst in the liver typically appears as a solitary, well-circumscribed lesion with a homogeneous, anechoic (or sometimes mildly hypoechoic) center on ultrasound. It has thin, smooth walls and shows posterior acoustic enhancement, with no internal septations or debris. These features are consistent with a benign, fluid-filled structure, making a simple cyst the most likely diagnosis. Incorrect Options: A. Hydatid Cyst Hydatid cysts usually have internal septations, daughter cysts, or debris (hydatid sand) and often present with a more complex appearance on ultrasound. They typically show a multilocular or "wheel spoke" pattern rather than a simple, unilocular lesion. B. Caroli’s Disease Caroli’s disease is characterized by saccular dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts, often with a "central dot" sign, and is typically not presented as a solitary lesion. It usually involves multiple cystic areas within the liver rather than a single simple cyst. C. Liver Abscess A liver abscess often appears as a complex lesion with mixed echogenicity due to the presence of pus, debris, and sometimes gas. It usually has irregular margins and internal echoes, distinguishing it from the smooth, anechoic appearance of a simple cyst.

choices.text: Obliteration of angle between ileum nd cecum
Narrowing of distal end of cecum

questions.text: Which of the following fetures is not seen in ileocecal tuberculosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ileocecal tuberculosis (TB) is a common form of abdominal TB that primarily affects the ileocecal region due to its rich lymphoid tissue. The characteristic radiological findings result from chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and ulceration of the intestinal wall. Incorrect Options: A. Pulled-up Cecum Chronic inflammation and fibrosis in ileocecal TB cause retraction and fibrosis of the mesentery, leading to an elevated, pulled-up cecum rather than its usual dependent position. This is a key radiological feature in contrast to malignancies, which typically cause fixation rather than elevation. C. Obliteration of Angle Between Ileum and Cecum Normally, the ileocecal angle is distinct. In ileocecal TB, inflammation and fibrosis lead to obliteration of this angle, giving the ileocecal region a distorted, rigid, and contracted appearance. D. Narrowing of the Distal End of Cecum The distal cecum is often narrowed due to fibrotic strictures and chronic inflammation, leading to a conical or stenosed appearance. This is also associated with irregular thickening of the ileocecal valve.

choices.text: It usually occurs due to obstruction at neck of gall bladder
On HIDA scan, gall bladder is not visualised
Immediate cholecystectomy can never be done
Analgesics and intravenous fluids are best treatment

questions.text: Which of the following statements about acute cholecystitis is true
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) On HIDA scan, gall bladder is not visualized Acute cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, most commonly caused by gallstone obstruction at the cystic duct leading to bile stasis, infection, and inflammation. The Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid (HIDA) scan is a nuclear imaging test that evaluates bile flow from the liver to the gallbladder and intestines. Non-visualization of the gallbladder on HIDA scan is a hallmark of acute cholecystitis due to cystic duct obstruction. Incorrect Options: A. It usually occurs due to obstruction at the neck of the gallbladder While obstruction can occur at the neck of the gallbladder, most cases occur due to obstruction of the cystic duct (proximal to the neck). Cystic duct obstruction leads to bile stasis, bacterial proliferation, and gallbladder inflammation, making it the most common cause of acute calculous cholecystitis. C. Immediate cholecystectomy can never be done Early laparoscopic cholecystectomy (within 72 hours) is actually recommended for acute cholecystitis. Delayed surgery can increase complications such as gangrene, perforation, or sepsis. "Never" is an absolute term, making this statement incorrect. D. Analgesics and intravenous fluids are the best treatment Supportive management with IV fluids, analgesics, and antibiotics is initial treatment but is not definitive. Surgery (cholecystectomy) is the best definitive treatment in most cases. Percutaneous cholecystostomy may be used in critically ill patients who are not surgical candidates.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions the lead pipe appearance of the colon on a barium enema is seen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ulcerative colitis The lead pipe appearance of the colon on a barium enema is characteristic of ulcerative colitis (UC). This occurs due to chronic inflammation, loss of haustration, and colonic wall rigidity, leading to a smooth, featureless colon that resembles a "lead pipe." UC is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that primarily affects the mucosa and submucosa of the colon, starting from the rectum and progressing proximally. Over time, repeated episodes of inflammation lead to fibrosis and muscular atrophy, causing the typical lead pipe appearance on imaging. Incorrect Options: A. Amoebiasis Amoebic colitis (caused by Entamoeba histolytica) does not cause loss of haustration. Instead, barium studies may show flask-shaped ulcers or thumbprinting due to mucosal edema. C. Tuberculosis of the Colon Intestinal tuberculosis typically affects the ileocecal region and can cause: Strictures Narrowing of the cecum Deformed ileocecal valve Unlike UC, TB colitis does not lead to a uniform loss of haustration across the colon. D. Crohn’s Disease Crohn’s disease is another form of IBD but it causes skip lesions and cobblestone appearance, not a lead pipe colon. The disease involves the entire bowel wall (transmural inflammation), leading to: String sign (narrowing of lumen due to fibrosis) Fistulas and strictures Cobblestone mucosa (due to ulceration and regeneration)

questions.text: A 55 year old male presents with features of obstructive jaundice. He also reports weight loss of seven kilograms in last two months. On Ct scan, the CBD is dialated till the lower end and the main pancreatic duct is also dialated. Pancreas is normal. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Periampullary Carcinoma Periampullary carcinoma refers to malignancies arising within 2 cm of the ampulla of Vater, which includes cancers of the: Pancreatic head Distal common bile duct (CBD) Ampulla of Vater Duodenum Key Features in the Given Case: Obstructive jaundice ? Due to biliary obstruction. Weight loss ? Suggests malignancy. CT scan findings: Dilated CBD up to the lower end ? Indicates obstruction at or near the ampulla. Dilated main pancreatic duct (Double duct sign) ? Classic for periampullary tumors. Normal pancreas ? Rules out primary pancreatic malignancy. Since the CBD and pancreatic duct are dilated but the pancreas is normal, this strongly suggests a periampullary tumor causing obstruction at the ampulla of Vater. Incorrect Options: A. Choledocholithiasis Common bile duct stones can cause obstructive jaundice, but they do not cause pancreatic duct dilation. Additionally, a CT scan would likely show stones, and the weight loss suggests a malignancy, not a stone. B. Carcinoma of the Gallbladder Gallbladder cancer can cause obstructive jaundice, but it usually shows mass formation in the gallbladder fossa and not an isolated double duct dilation. CT typically shows an irregular mass at the gallbladder neck rather than just bile duct dilation. C. Hilar Cholangiocarcinoma Also known as Klatskin tumor, this occurs at the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts. It causes intrahepatic bile duct dilation without distal CBD dilation. In this case, the CBD is dilated up to the lower end, which rules out a hilar lesion.

choices.text: The sensitivity of angiography for detecting GI bleeding is about 10-20% as compared to nuclear imaging
Angiography can image bleeding at a rate of 0.05/0.1 ml/min or less
99m Tc RBC scan image bleeding at rates as low as 0.05 – 0.1 ml/min
Angiography will detect bleeding only if extravasation is occurring during the injection of contrast

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect statement regarding GI bleeding
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Angiography can image bleeding at a rate of 0.05/0.1 ml/min or less Angiography is a valuable but less sensitive technique for detecting gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding compared to nuclear imaging. However, the rate at which angiography can detect bleeding is higher (i.e., it requires a faster rate of bleeding) than what is stated in option B. Correct Information Regarding Angiography & GI Bleeding: Angiography requires an active bleeding rate of at least 0.5 – 1.0 mL/min to detect extravasation. Nuclear imaging (99m Tc-labeled RBC scan) is more sensitive, detecting bleeding at rates as low as 0.05 – 0.1 mL/min, which is why it is preferred for occult or intermittent bleeding. Since option B falsely claims that angiography can detect bleeding at 0.05 – 0.1 mL/min, which is incorrect, it is the wrong statement in this question. Incorrect Options: A. The sensitivity of angiography for detecting GI bleeding is about 10-20% as compared to nuclear imaging Angiography is less sensitive than nuclear scans for detecting lower rates of GI bleeding, as it requires active bleeding at the time of contrast injection. Nuclear imaging can detect intermittent or low-flow bleeding, making it more sensitive. C. 99m Tc RBC scan images bleeding at rates as low as 0.05 – 0.1 mL/min This is correct because radionuclide scans are highly sensitive and can detect slow, intermittent bleeding at very low rates (0.05 – 0.1 mL/min). This makes them ideal for detecting chronic or occult GI bleeds. D. Angiography will detect bleeding only if extravasation is occurring during the injection of contrast Angiography requires active bleeding at the moment of contrast injection to visualize the extravasation of contrast into the GI tract. If bleeding has stopped at the time of imaging, angiography will not detect the source.

questions.text: Which one of the following hepatic lesions can be diagnosed with high accuracy using nuclear imaging
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH) Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH) is a benign liver lesion that can be accurately diagnosed using nuclear imaging, specifically 99mTc-labeled sulfur colloid scintigraphy. FNH contains Kupffer cells, which take up technetium-99m (99mTc) sulfur colloid, making it appear "hot" (increased uptake) on nuclear scans. This is a key distinguishing feature, as most other liver tumors (e.g., hepatocellular carcinoma, hepatic adenoma, cholangiocarcinoma) lack Kupffer cells and do not show uptake. This high specificity makes nuclear imaging particularly useful for diagnosing FNH. Incorrect Options: A. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) HCC lacks Kupffer cells, so it does not take up sulfur colloid on nuclear scans. Best diagnostic tests for HCC: Multiphasic CT or MRI with contrast (showing arterial enhancement & venous washout). AFP (alpha-fetoprotein) levels for screening and diagnosis. B. Hepatic Adenoma Hepatic adenomas do not contain Kupffer cells, so they do not show uptake on nuclear imaging. Preferred diagnostic test: MRI with hepatobiliary contrast (Gadoxetate - Eovist) is the best imaging modality. CT scan can also help, showing well-defined, hypervascular lesions. D. Cholangiocarcinoma Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) does not have Kupffer cells and does not take up sulfur colloid. Preferred diagnostic test: MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) Multiphasic contrast-enhanced CT or MRI CA 19-9 levels (tumor marker for cholangiocarcinoma).

questions.text: On barium swallow posterior indentation is seen due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Aberrant Right Subclavian Artery (ARSA) A posterior indentation on a barium swallow can be caused by an aberrant right subclavian artery (ARSA), also known as dysphagia lusoria. In this condition, the right subclavian artery arises abnormally from the descending aorta instead of the brachiocephalic trunk. As the artery courses behind the esophagus, it creates a posterior indentation on barium swallow, typically at the level of T3-T4. It may cause dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) due to esophageal compression, hence the term dysphagia lusoria. Incorrect Options: A. Left Atrium The left atrium is located anterior to the esophagus. An enlarged left atrium (e.g., in mitral stenosis) causes an anterior indentation, not a posterior one. B. Aortic Knuckle The aortic arch crosses behind the esophagus but does not create a significant posterior indentation. Instead, it creates a left-sided indentation on a barium swallow, typically at T4-T5. D. Pulmonary Artery Sling A pulmonary artery sling occurs when the left pulmonary artery originates from the right pulmonary artery and passes between the trachea and esophagus. This leads to anterior and lateral compression, not posterior indentation

questions.text: ‘’string of beads’’ apppearence on horizontal abdominal view xray is suggestive of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO) The "String of Beads" sign on a horizontal abdominal X-ray is a hallmark feature of small bowel obstruction (SBO). This appearance is caused by the presence of multiple air-fluid levels in a dilated small bowel. Due to fluid accumulation and gas trapping, air collects in small pockets between the valvulae conniventes, creating the characteristic bead-like appearance. This is best visualized on an upright or decubitus X-ray and is an early radiographic sign of SBO. Incorrect Options: A. Intussusception Intussusception presents with the "target sign" or "coiled spring sign" on X-ray or ultrasound, not the string of beads. It occurs when one segment of bowel telescopes into another, commonly seen in children. B. Sigmoid Volvulus Sigmoid volvulus shows a "coffee bean sign" or "omega sign" due to a dilated sigmoid colon. It does not produce the string of beads appearance, as it affects the large bowel rather than the small intestine. D. Large Bowel Obstruction (LBO) LBO shows haustral markings and often a "bird's beak sign" in volvulus cases. It does not create the string of beads appearance, which is characteristic of small bowel involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following gall bladder pathology can be diagnosed on simple abdominal xray and patient can be considered for cholecystectomy even on basis of xray finding
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Porcelain Gallbladder Porcelain gallbladder is a rare but significant finding on a simple abdominal X-ray. It is characterized by calcification of the gallbladder wall, which appears as a rim-like or complete radiopaque shadow in the right upper quadrant (RUQ). It is associated with a high risk of gallbladder carcinoma, and therefore, cholecystectomy is recommended even if the diagnosis is made on X-ray alone. The condition results from chronic inflammation and fibrosis, leading to calcium deposition within the gallbladder wall. Incorrect Options: A. Cholesterosis Cholesterosis ("strawberry gallbladder") is a benign condition involving cholesterol deposits in the gallbladder wall. It is not detectable on a plain X-ray, as it does not cause calcification. Diagnosis is usually made via ultrasound or histopathology, and cholecystectomy is not mandatory unless symptomatic. C. Limey Gallbladder Limey gallbladder refers to the presence of milk of calcium bile, seen as a layered, radiopaque density in the gallbladder on X-ray. Unlike porcelain gallbladder, it does not necessarily indicate malignancy. Management depends on symptoms; cholecystectomy is not mandatory. D. Diverticulosis of Gallbladder Gallbladder diverticulosis is a rare congenital or acquired condition where outpouchings (diverticula) form in the gallbladder wall. It is not typically visible on plain X-ray and is better diagnosed using ultrasound or CT scan. Cholecystectomy is not routinely indicated unless complications arise.

questions.text: The investigation of choice for acute appendicitis in children is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ultrasonography (USG) Ultrasonography (USG) is the investigation of choice for acute appendicitis in children due to the following reasons: Non-invasive and radiation-free: Unlike CT scans, USG does not expose children to ionizing radiation, making it a safer option. High sensitivity and specificity: USG can detect features such as an enlarged, non-compressible appendix (>6 mm in diameter), periappendiceal fluid collection, or increased echogenicity of surrounding fat. Real-time assessment: Helps in identifying appendicitis and ruling out other causes of abdominal pain like mesenteric adenitis or intussusception. In equivocal cases, CT scan may be considered for confirmation, but USG remains the first-line imaging modality. Incorrect Options: A. Barium Study Not used in acute appendicitis as it has no role in emergency diagnosis. Barium studies can exacerbate perforation risk in case of appendicitis. C. CT Scan Although highly accurate, it is not the first choice in children due to radiation exposure. CT is reserved for equivocal cases where USG is inconclusive. D. MRI MRI provides good soft tissue contrast but is not practical due to higher cost, longer scanning time, and limited availability in emergencies. It is not routinely used for diagnosing acute appendicitis in children.

questions.text: Best radiological investigation for insulinoma is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT Scan) Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT) is the best radiological investigation for insulinoma due to its ability to: Identify small pancreatic tumors: Insulinomas are often small (<2 cm) and located in the pancreas, making high-resolution imaging necessary. Detect vascular enhancement: Since insulinomas are hypervascular tumors, CECT can highlight them during the arterial phase of contrast enhancement. Provide anatomical details: Helps in surgical planning by precisely locating the tumor. CECT is widely available, non-invasive, and provides rapid diagnosis, making it the first-line imaging modality for insulinomas. Incorrect Options: A. PET Scan PET scans are not the primary choice for detecting insulinomas, as these tumors are often too small for PET imaging. However, 68Ga-DOTATATE PET-CT may be useful in detecting metastatic or malignant insulinomas. C. MRI MRI can be useful in detecting insulinomas, especially in patients with contrast allergies or when CT is inconclusive. However, it is less sensitive than CECT for detecting small insulinomas. D. Radionuclide Scan Radionuclide imaging (Octreotide scan) is mainly used for detecting neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) with somatostatin receptors, but most insulinomas do not express these receptors well. Less effective for detecting small insulinomas compared to CECT.
